message.content:
cs.GT, cs.CR, cs.AI, cs.SI, cs.IT

Reasoning: The paper proposes a game-theoretic framework to model the strategic behaviors of the deceiver and deceivee in a deception game. This suggests that the paper belongs to the Game Theory (cs.GT) sub-category. Additionally, the paper discusses the impacts of direct deception costs and players' conflict of interest on the deceivability, which falls under the sub-category of Cryptography and Security (cs.CR). The use of signaling game model to capture the information-asymmetric, dynamic, and strategic behaviors of deceptions suggests that the paper also belongs to the sub-categories of Artificial Intelligence (cs.AI) and Social and Information Networks (cs.SI). Finally, the analysis of the fundamental limits of deceivability suggests that the paper also belongs to the sub-category of Information Theory (cs.IT).
